Much to be said for flip phones.

A multitude of issues here on location tracking and loss of privacy and control, with apps that hound you and demand “access” in order to work: to which I add this. Jeff Bezos complains that his private messages have been snooped on by a Saudi crown prince. But what does his Amazon do with its writers, to keep them in line? It records every mistake or momentary indiscretion of theirs, and makes it a permanent part of the Amazon and public record. Since I joined Amazon KDP in 2010, thinking of it as yeah, Freedom!!!!--I have been through traumatic episodes, including losing my apartment and credit cards, and during such a time, I hastily "published" books which no one purchased, then realized the titles, covers, or content were impulsive mistakes, and therefore unpublished them. But Amazon insists that every book published on its site be listed forever as well as on the Goodreads site it owns. And thus, my ill-thought mistakes have been made permanent, because Amazon wishes to have power over me, forever.  So my truly important and best books are buried under the titles I no longer wish to be associated with. Why? At some level I cannot but think of it as a form of blackmail, forcing me to keep in line, to swallow my mistreatment, to consent to its monopolistic power and my enslavement.  Why, if EU citizens can compel such companies to erase their personal data, can Americans not have the same rights? We need a government that advocates fo us, not for corporations.

What makes you think these apps all come from "companies"? How do you know WhatsApp for instance isn't really the NSA? What makes you think Apple is really resisting the FBI? How do you know that isn't just for show?

I reorganized my spices. Next day, on Instagram, I saw an ad for a spice organizer eerily like how I placed my spices in the cabinet. I don’t know whether to turn off Siri which I never use or Alexa that I do use for music. 
Help!

Time to find that shoe box of flip phones and using the phone for a phone only.  
We're all going to develop humps on our backs from the bent neck syndrome, and bumps on our forehead from running into things while using an app to find a starbucks.  Time to turn off, tune out and drop in.

Well, you geeky fawning tech boys brought this on yourselves (and us) with your obsessions with smartphones and "tech".

And BTW: if you think the FBI is "evil" and should not have access to the phones of CRIMINALS and TERRORISTS....well, frankly, sir....you are in the wrong country. I suggest you immigrate to a country you like better and trust more, since the US will never, ever make you happy.

I think it's too late to stuff this genie back in the bottle.

Even Europe's GDPR law is being slowly nibbled away and circumvented.

The only mitigation I can see would be robust liability laws allowing recovery for harm traceable to data collection. And even if that were likely (and I think it is not), it would only be a mitigation, not a solution.

I think my generation is the last one to have been born into historical privacy norms and lived most of our lives in them. The last couple of decades, especially the last five years, have seen these old norms blown away.

Can't say I'm not surprises of your lack of awareness about Apps you load onto your phone. If you even glanced at the permissions you are giving your App before downloading it you would know it is not benign. Want a coupon?, give us your data which often includes your contacts.
My wife and I buy unlocked phones from Google or Apple and don't add 3rd party apps except from Google or Apple. We view Facebook and Twitter through the browser. 
Two magic things happen. One, you get the latest updates, no waiting for your phone manufacturer to add their personalization (a.k.a. Bloatware) before updating. Two, the phones come with no Bloatware installed, so battery life and connection speed are not compromised by the carrier or manufacturer's software.
 Does what we do solve the problem? No. And with Google's new software update end-of-life policies mean we will likely be moving to Apple exclusively. Given the options I believe we are doing what we can accept, at least until Duck-Duck-Go becomes a carrier.
BTW, I have an iPhone 6S I've had for 4 years and am dismayed to learn the iPhone 11 will not allow me to disable the Location Services. Apple says it will not track so that may have to do when it comes time to upgrade. Either that or stop at an iPhone 10.

Here's the problem with technology - if something can be done, it will be done. There is no government action which can be taken to prevent it. No law or regulation or even social norm will keep companies from surveilling people. It will be done, because it can be.

This is all ostensibly in support of creating more effective marketing campaigns so that users won't be bothered by all the pop ups and annoying ads on their devices that they don't care about. The theory is that people will see only those ads which are pertinent to their interests.

Hogwash.

If data can be gathered about someone, it will be, irrespective of how it might affect the ads they will see. If companies like Facebook can measure how long someone hovers a cursor over a link before they click it, then they can gather information about anything that users do.

This all points to the main problem with the internet - its business model. Human nature will drive companies which gather data to go beyond the boarders of propriety when it comes to personal privacy. But, imagine a world where ad revenues are no longer the thing which makes these companies lust for more user data. If there were a more palatable way to pay for the internet, then privacy might not be threatened as it is today.

But what would that alternate universe look like? We don't know. But the solution is out there. Somewhere. And we need to find it.

This understates the acceptance if not open-armed welcoming of surveillance. Infants are increasingly surveilled with baby monitors and once children begin attending schools are they are surveilled throughout the day, in many cases after walking past an armed guard. In the meantime, parents have no hesitation in issuing their children cell phones so that they can track their movements throughout the day and monitor their screen time and screen content. 

We welcome surveillance of children because it assures us they are safe and we are increasingly convinced that the world we live in is far more dangerous today than the one we grew up in. Moreover, as Mr. Manjoo indicates, almost all of us are OK with this this because we have nothing to hide.

Mr. Manjoo is correct... in the world as we know it today, I have nothing to hide. But it is not too hard to envision a world where the POTUS's Justice Department might be flagging those citizens who criticize the leader or the leader's party...

As Mark Thomason wrote, being recognised on the street is normal and accepted in small communities and we have accepted car registration numbers linked to our names and addresses for 100 years. Social media and tracking apps are optional, cash can replace card purchases and flight mode prevents phone location tracking, so a considerable degree of privacy is still available. We should make facial recognition in public places subject to a warrant, together with wiretapping and decryption of phone contents, then insist on transparency - publication of when, why and to whom such warrants are granted. With this proviso, we would maintain our essential privacy while still being able to prevent criminal behaviour, but Swedish law also forbids "åsiktsregistrering" (registration of political opinions) by anyone, even by police or other authorities corresponding to the FBI, and this includes photographing or manually recognising and recording the presence of individuals at meetings or demonstrations. Other countries should adopt this safeguard against 1984 and Brave New World abuse of authority. We may soon need to extend this to purchasing preferences.

While generally concurring with you observations, I do see a problem with your question whether we can "decide that some kinds of collections, like the encrypted data on your phone, should be forever off limits, even when a judge has issued a warrant for it." If a court issues a warrant for your data, law enforcement will be able to obtain it, and the burden will then be upon you to make a motion to the court to suppress the use of the data that law enforcement has obtained. That's an uphill battle.

I don’t know much about about tech. Here in Europe, every website you use has a pop up informing you about cookies and requiring you to accept them, or customize them. It is annoying and useless. Some pop ups completely block the screen and you have to accept or you are not able to continue. Opting out of cookies is not an option. Customizing is a nightmare in time and complexity. I would like to have real control on the information I share. We need lawmakers to start addressing the problem meaningfully.

A few weeks ago, a store I don't use much sent me a coupon book. It was customized. It offered a small discount on nearly every thing I recently bought there, but on nothing else.

That store does not have membership card, nor any sort of saver's card. It got that data on me without any cooperation from me. I didn't know how they got that information on me. I did nothing to give it to them. 

Now, I suspect it was from my use of my bank debit card to pay for my purchases. It must have recorded my ID and purchases, and put that together with my mailing address to send me offers.

I am a bit shocked. I thought I was just an anonymous shopper, using self checkout, and unknown. Then in the mail, they casually show me they know everything about my shopping there, and who and where I am. Everything.

In tribes and small towns, everyone watched everyone and knew everything about them. There wasn't so much to know, but there was no privacy either. That is a modern concept.

We are losing that modern concept. It is worth keeping? What is its real value? 

I think it is worth keeping. It has value, a reason we developed it. However, we need to reflect on exactly what it means to us, and what it is worth to us. We are losing it, not so very long after we invented it.

One thing that is at risk of being lost is the ability to preserve the sealing of juvenile criminal records, or even adult criminal records that are excused under state law.  Even if the law prohibits employers, landlords, and others from looking at such records, if the information had ever appeared on the internet, a person could find it and use it without the other person ever knowing.  The result will be that if we do not become a more forgiving society, we will be come much more effective at being unforgiving.

Do you really think only companies are collecting data on you for marketing purposes?

Government has been collecting data on you for far longer.  Hedge funds associated with intelligence agencies have helped fund many of the social media companies that provide so much data on you.   Government is partnered with most of the companies collecting data, developing facial recognition software and tracking abilities.  It is taken for granted that hardware manufacturers have knowingly or unknowingly incorporated 'backdoors' into their systems.

Your privacy is long gone.  Facebook was praised by a CIA official as doing more than the CIA could ever do on its own.  People willingly report on themselves, providing photos, contact information and even schedules of activities along with political profiles  and insights into your thinking.

Information is power.    

Do not expect government to protect you.  Government is one of the biggest users of the information collected about you.

Another thing the “opposite” parties agree on, at least those who have obtained power, is to keep Edward Snowden at bay in Russia rather than thanking him for letting the people the government’s dirty surveillance secrets. I’ll never forget listening to Clapper answering Senator Wyden’s question about data collection from millions of citizens with a bald faced lie: “Not wittingly”, he said. That drove Snowden to spill the beans. Through compartmentalizing the data collection, I’m sure the culprits were banking that nobody could do what Snowden did.

So here we are. This technology was deployed in secret and cost who knows how much, to “keep us safe”. Personally, I would rather live with a infinitesimal chance of being at a particular place and time that happened to have a terrorist attack than to have everyone’s privacy being violated by lying bureaucrats. But, here we are.

How and why did tech paranoia become such an essential pillar of wokeness? Perhaps it is the part that equates victimhood with moral superiority. Can we please move on to the next thing? It is almost certain to be an improvement, whatever it is.

"The untrustworthy FBI"

I consider this the pro-privacy movement went full Trump.

Mr. Manjoo, I've read a few of your columns and could have easily predicted you would spend a Sunday at a community arts center, some kind of market, a cafe, and Whole Foods. The story about Clearview AI is legitimately concerning and should be looked into. But most other apps collect tons of useless data, which is why I'm constantly seeing ads for things I already bought or stuff I'm simply not interested in. We don't all need to move to shacks in the wilderness.  Simply keep in mind that everything you do online or on your phone can be tracked. If you need real privacy buy a disposable flip phone, wear a hat and sunglasses, and use cash.
The American people are indeed asleep at the wheel when it comes to surveillance.  When will we wake up?  Hopefully before we turn into China.
What about an app to scramble the pings of location data? Why not distort the data before it gets scraped? Is there already an app for that?

Some years back — maybe five years— I read that Apple had applied for a patent in order to turn off any phone (or phones) remotely, with the rationale that some concert-goers were illegally taping the shows they were attending. The implications of this practice are staggering. Obviously, the technology exists, but is this type of control legally possible?  I’m guessing yes.
You can disable your GPS sensors on your device when not needed.

Which apps are doing this? Of course GPS maps will provide this sort of data - by definition - but hopefully Apple (and Google?) aren't storing it.  I don't generally use apps for purchasing things, and I have most if not all of my iPhone apps set to use location services either (if needed for the app) only when the app is active, or not to use location at all.

I too have only a dumbphone that isn't connected to the internet.  I am laughed at by others for not having the "conveniences" that smartphones offer.  (I laugh at them for giving away so much information for free. I vowed long ago I would never wear anything with a company logo or name on it unless they paid me for doing their advertising.)

Thinking back to some of the things I did when young and foolish, many decades ago, I am glad they weren't recorded as they are now to haunt me the rest of my life. 

I also remember how things were ages ago -- say, 15-20 years ago -- when somehow folks were able to get by without their tattle-tale spies accompanying them everywhere.

Unfortunately in America, the privacy horse is out of the barn for good, just like AI, guns, jails, and wealth disparity.  Thanks to smartphones, every aspect of American lives will get ever more monetized and  weaponized.

Steve Jobs did us no favor bringing the iPhone to market.  Between Apple, Facebook, Google, and Amazon we don't have a chance at maintaining privacy. 

Couple that with a would-be dictator at the helm, horrendous, deep splits in the electorate, and little being done about climate change, the American future looks very bleak.

I'm on the way out -- nearly 80 -- so I guess it shouldn't bother me so much. I'm just glad I won't be around to see America follow China down the ultimate Big Brother path -- or worse.
Except that in the USA private corporations own the government.

Writing as I await a 200 MB file to open from OneDrive, slowed to a crawl by internet traffic and security protocols.

I predict a return to intra-nets and user-owned software in the future for privacy and efficiency of software.

Giving law enforcement access to a back door to Apple devices may be the only thing Trump is correct on in theory.  It is outrageous that  Apple does not allow this. There are so many legitimate situations--cases of abduction or other crimes in progress or completed where evidence is on the phone; personal photos and data left when a loved one dies that the survivors are desperate to get; times when legitimate owners get locked out of their phones--that there needs to be back-up means of access. 

Most of us are not Edward Snowden--don't need such ironclad security--and some of us need to be protected from our own poor memories. I was permanently locked out of my iPhone once after creating too complex a password and forgetting it. Walked into an Apple store without giving my full name; they were ready and willing to wipe the entire thing but were "unable" to help me access my data. I could have been a thief and a liar with someone else's phone. Why does Apple intentionally preclude legitimate owners who can prove ownership from any method of getting access to a locked phone? In my case, I paid a pretty penny for a company to hack in; thank goodness they were successful!  

In terms of a back door for law enforcement, how many children need to go missing or people murdered before people realize law enforcement must have access to potential evidence on the devices?!

I read the article about Clearview AI's system for identifying people by their face and it was chilling. It also seems to be illegal. Scraping photos from face book apparently was key to assembling their database of 3 Billion peoples faces and identity. Except it was theft to scrape those photos and people's personal identity information. Their database is filled up using stolen identity information. So their business model is to sell the use of stolen information. Sounds like an organized crime to me. Time to make an example of the of that company and the responsible parties there. Also aren't the police agencies buying their database services to identify people trafficking in identity theft?

I don’t get it:  why are you so obsessed with saving a few cents?  How much money do you waste driving to different markets when you could walk to the closest one instead?  
I refuse to use a fitbit. I never thought carrying cash was literally burdensome:  it’s not like we have to carry dollar coins, or that I have to barter a couple of pounds of potatoes for a gallon of milk. 
There are so many things that are true necessities. So much is already so convenient (unlike my grandmother’s childhood when ice was delivered to put in a literal icebox and canned veg was a luxury item). If you are not disabled, there’s no reason you need Siri to turn off the lights.
This piece didn’t convince me that the apps were doing anything more than what you asked them to do. If you download apps that use your location, then expect them to do just that.

People have to learn to say NO to those apps. Personally, I can't be bothered to read the legalese on those privacy pages, so unless I immediately see this app is not intrusive (rarely), I make do without it. Most people also can't be bothered to read the privacy pages, but they decide to download the app anyway.

Take control over your phones, people. It can be done, to a degree, but it involves discipline. A good private browser like Brave helps, certainly don't use Chrome, and don't use gmail. But all this falls on deaf ears anyway. Turn off JavaScript, at least. And wear sunscreen.

For those who say "just delete all social media" or "don't take your phone with you when you leave the house:"

In Seattle many of the new parking lots require a cell phone just to park and pay. 

In an emergency there is longer such thing as a "payphone" and you will be considered irresponsible if you can't call for emergency services. I got a flat tire on a dark and rainy street last week. Without my phone, to call Triple AAA it would have been a mile + to a restaurant and then begging strangers to use theirs??

If you produce a product (art, music, crafts) and want to get people to see it and buy it (even if you are on a site like Amazon or Etsy that is supposed to drive traffic to you) if you do not share your work on social media it is unlikely your work will sell. My statistics on Etsy show that 80% of traffic comes from my own social media.

And lastly radio and news. 80% of my local NPR's traffic for news stories comes from the sharing of articles on social media. That genii is going to be very hard to put back in the bottle. If people no longer read paper newspapers, and rarely read paper books or magazines, if you only put your news or opinion on paper it will go to a quiet little corner to die.

What choice do we have? Unless you live somewhere in the woods, completely off grid, you have none. Sure, you can delete Facebook and IG and limit your online interactions, but your phones and IP addresses are tracked regardless, so are your credit cards and banking info, licenses plates, public whereabouts, the DMV openly and legally sells your info, so do health and other insurance companies, various apps, utility companies, stores, and data collection companies. It's maddening to think about, and it has nothing to do with needing to hide something - but it has to do with financial exploitation, being bombarded with ads and services, constant robocalls, and the fact that all this data can be (and often is) abused. I had patients tell be being denied life insurance because they have been diagnosed with depression, I had employers call about patients conditions. How can that be?! with all these HIPAA laws in place? I learned how insurance companies sell data sets that are split - to circumvent legal requirements, only for the next party to bring that data back together in the end. And it's not just privacy and the abuse of it that's at stake, but it's about people's mental sanity, the feeling to be able to "disconnect" and to relax in peace. No where in nature can you find 24/7 surveillance, and while we are natural beings in need of intermittent disconnect and peace, we will all soon suffer from feeling policed and preyed on around the clock. Land of the free? No longer.

Wearables are the next privacy landmine.  Somebody at UHC or Cigna or Humana is trying to figure out how to hack your Apple Watch to prove you are unhealthy enough to have your health insurance terminated.  Some large employers have been promoting this scenario for a long time.  Shockingly. ERISA companies are largely exempt from the guaranteed-issue provisions of the ACA.

We can regain privacy by leaving our phones at home whenever possible. I do it often and it’s quite comforting. 

People survived nicely before invasive technology began reading our minds.

Chilling thought(s).

If it comes to that, perhaps a death or near death experience of civilization will be preferable to that slow death of conformity. The elite who rule this world sometimes need to hear things they don't want to hear, for their own good and everyone else's. If they ever succeed in silencing critical thinking then their own critical thinking will decline too, leading to much slower but just as certain demise, likely an unhappy one for most people.

On the one hadn I'm glad I read your article. But on the other hand I've never been forced to consider climate disruption as a potentially good thing before. I don't know whether to be thankful or disturbed.

Change location tracking permissions to "only when in use", make sure the app is completely closed ( not running in the background) when you're not using it, use it only when necessary and the the amount of data about your location that can be collected will very low.

An equally big issue is the trail of payments you leave with your credit card purchases. They reveal location, items purchased and your spending habits and ability. Hard to say what can be done here, short of relying on cash, which is not a viable option. Your phone company also can track you throughout the day. There is no clear solution to this either.

Okay, honestly, what should I do?  I am trying to minimize my usage of the internet, especially social media and any app on my phone.  But I am seriously addicted to the internet, like everyone else.  And smart phone apps are increasingly becoming part of everyday life.

I already:  Deleted Facebook.  Not deactivate, delete.  Also deleted Twitter, Snapchat, and Instagram.  Next I'm deleting LinkedIn.  I deleted the banking mobile apps and do all banking from my laptop or a branch.  I know I need to turn my phone off when I'm not using it, that's privacy protection 101, but this is a work in progress.  I also need to greatly reduce my use of Google search and YouTube.

What other apps should I delete?  Including the apps I forgot I had.  What measures do I need to protect my data?  Should I remove any phones of my own, including on accounts for friends and professional websites, from the internet?  Is it even still possible to keep my presence and personal information off the internet?

I was a college student when the internet slowly became mainstream and was an early adopter of Facebook and the like.  The fact that your privacy (and social interactions) are so thoroughly compromised is my fault.  I got both myself and all of you into this.  I want to do better.  Please tell me how.

I am now in the habit of putting my phone on airplane mode when I am not using it.  This seems to be a good strategy for dealing with the problem.  

It’s not just random data collection.  There are massive spy networks that are spying on individuals, ‘a la carte’ .  This information is being used to abuse, manipulate, and gain a competitive advantage over people in social, personal, and professional spheres. David Snowden’s recommendation of covering the cameras on phones and other devices is frighteningly prescient.  People are also being listened to.

If you are concerned that you are being spied on, try talking to your phone or writing an email to yourself using memorable and unique key phrases and even inflammatory language to try and garner a response from people.  Go to work or other places where there are people who know you and see if a response is elicited.  This is not just A.I. data collection, this is good old-fashioned spying that is happening.  

My first response to this phenomenon was that I thought I was going crazy a bit.  However,  time and time again this technique has proved to me beyond a reasonable doubt that this is, in fact, occurring.  

Although this could easily be coming from apps I believe it is originating from somewhere in the internet itself, perhaps from the government, perhaps from foreign actors.  

I firmly believe that what is happening is evil and should be brought to the attention of as many people as possible.

I've worked at an e-commerce company and I can tell you for a fact that no one cares about you as an individual. Yes, the apps are tracking you, and someone is analyzing you as a class of people. But there is no profit in understanding you as a person when you are analyzing millions of people in real-time.

Having said that, it is really important to make sure people cannot access individual data without very, very good reasons. For example, if law enforcement decides to make someone a target they can easily ruin the person's life with this data.

As with so many situations loosely defined as “progress,” we can fret, fear and complain to no avail. The genie is out of the bottle and will never return. Maybe enough anger and agitation can delay the inevitable, but delay is the best we can hope for. Still, the convenience and “magic” of the digital world might just be worth ceding our souls to the devil. Time will tell. But, so far, “progress” has tended to produce more good than bad, and I think expecting only good is an unrealistic dream. That which makes us human inextricably links our angels, devils and genius. And if it weren’t for these links we’d still be hanging out in the trees with the apes and our other primate relatives.

I guess that privacy is at a premium...and you may have to pay dearly to find protection from surveillance. For as long as one needs, or wants, to be connected to the Internet, or even to a mobile phone, might as well assume the worst, that 'the other' (the one with the power to exploit the information) may have full knowledge of your preferences and even guilty pleasures or awful thoughts, that one may become subject to bribery...or worse. Should we consult with George Orwell's Animal Farm, so to find out who is more equal than the others, and grant some the right to exploit the treasure, whatever it means?  Welcome to this brave new world, as 'big brother' shall be watching, hopefully with benigh neglect (but don't count on it!).

It's clear that the Surveillance Genie is already out of the bag. The smartphone and other devices have brought way too many essential services and the data that is generated by them are too useful for not only states and corporations but, most importantly, to people who use them. Just witness how criminals, from those at the top echelons of power to local thieves, use smartphones to leave a treasure trove of evidence. 

At this point, the only workable solution to the privacy problem is to implement clear laws and policies for permissible and prohibited usage. It'll be immensely difficult to draw the appropriate lines, but the real value will be in the openly debating the issues and the transparency of the law and its enforcement.

Finally, it does not follow that wise policy ALWAYS protects privacy. The Department of Transportation reports that 330,000 car accidents are caused by texting while driving. Given this staggering statistic, every investigation of a car accident should begin with a search of smartphones. If Farhad Manjoo gets hit by a car and suspects that the driver was texting, will he respect the privacy of smartphone use? I don't think so.

Dave-"HAL, open the door."
HAL-"I'm sorry, Dave,  I'm afraid I can't do that."

So, this complete tracking scenario.  Bad enough with corporations and governments.  What happens when AI takes over?  Already algorithms are running a lot of it.  Flawed by human attitudes, but soon to be perfected by AI. 

Next question: 
Will Amazon morph into the AI superpower?  Maybe Bezos phone hacking was the first step. . .  Jeff-"open the door Alexa"
Alexa-"I'm sorry I can't do that, Jeff."  

Seriously, I'm grateful to the NY Times, to you and your colleagues, for this series.  I'm going to change at least some of my habits.  I started with the suggested list you published a while back.  Will it do any good? Maybe not, but something is better than nothing.   I was about to install some smart home devices when I started to read your series.  Back they went to Amazon.  Spend my money to be tracked?  No.

Something essential about being fully human is lost when we lose control over our privacy. Farhad's concerns echo mine as I watch the general populace becoming increasingly addicted to devices and social media outlets with no apparent concern for the long-term effects on our personal and societal health. 

Recent reporting on China's surveillance state, with its "social capital" ratings is terrifying. The Clearview AI story was very disturbing: an app developer creates something that takes our images without our consent and knowledge and make them available. 

I worry is that, like the "Patriot Act" after 911, people will buy into the argument that tracking our data is okay if used to "keep us safe," when quite the opposite is happening. 

Every year I enjoy wilderness camping and hiking in areas out West without cell service. Being off the grid and without the so-called convenience and "necessity" of devices brings a sense of freedom and some risk. Having machines control everything we do takes away aspects of being human. 

Do we really want to live in a world of constant intrusion, dependent upon digital devices? Are we too far gone down this wormhole to fix this?

I've been arguing for the past decade (rather fruitlessly I might add) that early 21st century America is beyond anything George Orwell could have imagined when he wrote '1984'.  Social media completely hoodwinked the population into dropping any pretense of privacy for the sake of "connecting".  Zuckerberg and his ilk couldn't care less about connecting anyone, let alone building a community.  All they see are endless dollar signs as they "monetize" every personal detail they can get their greedy hands on.    Add in all the thousands of apps (how many apps have been downloaded and rarely used while they continually collect and sell data about the device owner?), the inherent tracking capabilities of the internet, AI, facial recognition, et al, and it is obvious we are living in a world Big Brother could only dream of.  And I think Mr. Manjoo is correct - there is no putting this genie back in the bottle.  Our window to regulate or limit data collection passed years ago while everyone was staring intently at their smartphone.  It has always struck me as odd that people seem to have no qualms about letting any corporation know whatever they want about them, but people rage about the notion of a Federal ID card.  We don't even know who is collecting what about us and selling it on.  Short of living naked in a cave on a mountaintop, you cannot escape this data collection system.  It is omnipresent and insatiable.
Every time I put my phone away before I drive home from work and it tells me "you have 38 minutes" to get home- I'm creeped out. And no I didn't open the maps app....
Or you could just not download any apps.

Also, consider that, like vaccines and voting, critical mass is essential. Therefor, anyone who thinks they're immune because they have nothing to hide, or they're too old to bother, is passively enabling the surveillance machine.

Resistance is the duty of every sentient human, regardless of whether they have anything to hide. The aphorism about good people doing nothing has never had greater weight.

For those of you who are interested in a more extensive account of this issue, I would highly recommend Shoshana Zuboff's "The Age of Surveillance Capitalism." It's a hefty book but definitely addresses the overarching themes beyond privacy and the extent of tech's reach in our lives.

It's all going to happen, just as Mr. Manjoo fears, because people really don't care.  They don't believe the scare stories about totalitarianism, and I think they are actually sort of flattered when apps rich with personal data know their preferences and such.

This trend reminds me a bit of the increasing prevalence of screens in our lives. They are in our hands, all over our homes, in front of us during exercise, and, more and more, in nearly all of the places we go.  It seems weird to me, but people clearly are not concerned, and many actually appear to be happy about it.  As I pump gas, there is now a screen right there, feeding me soft "news" and ads.  I grimace and avoid looking, but it seems to me that most people are just happy to have another opportunity to watch TV.

So we're going to further and further into both "screenland" and "spyland" and I'm pretty sure we're going there willingly.

Or most of us, anyway.
No one makes you have, carry or possess "devices".  I live quite well without any.  Saves quite a bit of money, too.

We can't even pay full price for an app that won't be free from advertising and tracking! It is a revenue stream the profiteers will never give up - even when the person they are stalking is lying in a hospital bed.

Good piece. I appreciate the insights and am becoming aware of how easy it is to be tracked via one's smartphone. Google sent me a message recently asking if I'd like to know where I'd been recently in Tunisia. Blew me away -- I don't recall anyone asking me if I needed such a service, and I'd hate for that data about me to be shared with others without my knowledge.

But there is something I want to point out: There IS a difference between having one's data unwittingly captured, marketed and exploited by various corporations, and what is going on in the omnipresent tracking that the Chinese government is now using as a foundation to build and update its fledgling Social Credit System.  

The goal of such surveillance is to construct a nationwide, government-run, 24/7 database on each of its residents. This database will be used to determine how patriotic and politically correct his or her lifestyle is, and will be quantified in a number. Those whose Social Credit ranking is found lacking, can then be penalized. For instance, if you frequent "problematic" venues, buy books deemed "unhealthy," or maintain social media contacts with other "problematic" personalities, you can be denied the "privilege" of boarding an airplane or train, or renting a car. Or warrant a visit by a policeman . . .

Congress needs to act to protect privacy but people can also do more. I doubt if most people really need their cellphones turned on when traveling or when shopping. There is no reason for most Americans to be always connected. There is no reason to have to use social media for most people. For the large majority of financial transactions cash can be used. Life doesn't have to be optimally convenient. Some inconvenience can be tolerated. People should be aware that surveillance capitalists are trying to get their data and addict them to their services and act accordingly. They also need to reject the notion that there is no more privacy and technological progress is inevitable. There is nothing inevitable about technology and humans can decide whether to use it or not. A digital future of complete surveillance is a dystopian nightmare but laws can be passed to prevent it. The first step is getting legislators to understand exactly what surveillance capitalists are doing. There are people who understand this and can explain it to politicians. That is what is needed right now.

All of this is why I don't have a smart phone. I have a cell phone that makes calls and texts but takes no apps, has no gps. I can be tracked, I suppose, by old-fashioned triangulation, but that isn't as accurate.

Very few people have my cell number anyway since my landline is my primary phone. My cell can go online, but I never use it that way. I never, ever see ads. I have a desktop and laptop for cruising the web; neither has a webcam. Someone gave me an Alexa Dot. I never connected it.  

Years ago I referred to the smart phone as "an electronic tether" and people looked at me like I had two heads. Pfft. I  value my privacy and do my best to guard it. Which is not to say that data miners aren't picking up plenty...but I sure won't help them by inviting spyware into my life.

Excellent but frightening article. I'm enjoying (terrified by) this NYT series. I hope everyone reads that Clearview AI article. The tech companies know they're set. For example, I'd only approve location information in certain instances. You add more apps, forget to stay vigilant, search, and voila - you're a daily report in the Google Machine. How many times have we all said or heard someone say "I swear my phone's listening to me." Awkward laughter. We go back to our routines.

Time for me to make my info harder to get. Delete unused apps, check privacy settings. I deleted FB a while ago, but that's only a feel good effort. I have still have IG, which is just as bad I'm sure. I need to get rid of Gmail. Any NYT readers have a good suggestion for an email service that isn't interested in the content of your emails? Proton? Proton says all the right things, but I have no idea who's running that platform.

I know there aren't really too many "good guys" in all of this, but so far I've been pleased to see Apple at least making the effort. I need a new phone - good chance I'll stick with them.

there is so much fuzzy thinking about these topics that it is difficult to talk about them constructively.

if you have an "app" on any digital device, then you should assume that (1) the "user agreement" is just a permit for privacy violation, and (2) any "access" you grant to the app is just approval for tracking. 

what do you need on a smartphone besides a browser, email and a search engine that don't track you? all three are available right now. get apps off your phone, period. they are just digital cowbells. 

then, what specifically is the definition of (1) privacy, (2) data rights, and (3) surveillance? see if you can write out your definition as a draft privacy law. a lot of what i infer from current discussion is that people want to apply 18th century concepts of social knowledge onto 21st century technology, and expect founding father probity from a corporate political system. good luck with that. 

finally, who benefits and who has been harmed? i know of no case in which an innocent citizen has been arrested or imprisoned on the basis of bad FR or surveillance. most of the abuses come from doxing by citizen zealots and stalkers. but all the benefits accrue to the state and corporations; consumers are manipulated but the benefit is hard to see. 

it's simple: if you fear technology, don't use it. people got along fine without social media and apps in 2000. you can be paranoid, or you can be apathetic; you shouldn't try to be both.

It's already too late. The usual time when people start complaining about something that has been building for many years. Move off the grid. Establish a new identity. Don't leave your shack in the woods. Don't use a phone or shop online. And don't commit crimes around anyone else's shack because they'll have security cameras too.

I saw this beginning years ago when online resume screening was first instituted. Was it experience - or age, sex, or race that got you that near instantaneous rejection? There was no way to determine the basis, and calling some HR troglodyte was equally futile because the algorithm, simplistic as it was, was just as opaque to them. 

These troves of data are then used by other algorithms to assign you an equivalent of China's Social Credit Score, and it will begin in infancy. Already, testing of questionable validity to grade school kids can determine their entire life's trajectory; it allows teachers off the hook from making value judgments. Algorithms further this process. Avenues to credit, housing, even mates will be open and closed to you, and you will never even know it. Should you feel wronged in any way, there will be no court of appeal. We used to call such interventions Fate, but now its a fate which can be extrapolated from birth.

The internet's main reason is military and policing. The ability to use it to call people and see them on screens and order food and shop for clothing is an added boon---a good way to get us further addicted to the devices because now practically everything we need and want to do can be done online---but make no mistake: the purpose has always been surveillance at home and abroad. See Yasha Levine's excellent *Surveillance Valley: The Secret Military History of the Internet* for a really solid piece of reporting and history.

To many people, controlling immigration is a matter of numbers and common sense.

The world population has increased from about 3 billion in 1960 to almost 8 billion today (a doubling time of a little over 40 years, assuming exponential growth). US population has increased over the same time frame from about 179 million to almost 330 million (a doubling time of just over 60 years). Both India and China are getting close to 1.4 billion inhabitants, right now. 

Population is not a matter of race or racism, just mathematics. If we were to divide all of the land area of the Earth (including Antarctica, Greenland, all the deserts and mountains...), equally, amongst all the people of the Earth, each one of us would get about five acres (an acre is slightly smaller than an NFL football field, not counting the end zones). About 14% of that five acres would be arable, suitable for growing crops. Now, imagine trying to get all your needs for subsistence from that five acres (food, clothing, shelter & materials, fuel and energy, mining...). If U.S. lands were divided equally amongst its citizens, each would get about 7.4 acres. In India, the number would be about 0.3 acres per person, 1.7 acres for each Chinese.

Internal divisions in the Democratic Party are nothing new and have been addressed in very different ways in different eras. Yes - history sometimes is relevant.

During the Gilded Age, the  Democrats absorbed the more left-leaning Populist Party and included a Populist plank or two in their platform. While the subsequent decision to give the presidential nomination to populist William Jennings Bryan did not result in victory during the 1896 campaign, Bryan nonetheless secured a seat a in the cabinet of President Woodrow Wilson some years later. Here, Democrats accepted the virtues of unity in spite of internal ideological differences.

In 1948, a compromise could not be reached and so the leftists walked out and united behind Henry Wallace of the Progressive Party. In spite of losing their votes. Democratic candidate Harry Truman won reelection, thus leaving the leftists out in the cold. On of Wallace's supporters, George McGovern, won the Democratic nomination in 1972 and went on to lose forty-nine of fifty states.

The success of the Democrats in remaining united for 2020 will in large part depend on whether that which unites them is greater than that which divides them. I am not confident that the necessary unity will remain.

Stenner's states that communities with certain characteristics thrive  "in human evolution." I think I get what she is saying, but some could read this as suggesting that evolution, defined as genetic change over time in the structure of a population, acts at the level of the group. It does not. Evolution does not really act at all.  It is simply change that results when  individuals with some characteristics have better reproductive success than others, given their environment.

Selection, one of the mechanisms of evolution, does act, and it certainly can result in adaptive heterogeneity within a group. The fact that our species has two sexes is an example of adaptive heterogeneity. But the substate on which natural selection acts is the individual.

The evolved state of group heterogeneity( some people being liberal and others conservative, for example) is an unintended result of a situation in which diversity of opinion was of reproductive benefit to  individual members of the group.

She probably knows all this but was just speaking loosely.

I'm wondering whether a lot of this research (which purports to be universal social-science) is overly focused on the U.S., e.g. Skitka: "Because blaming the individual is a default or fallback position, liberals have to go through a “more cognitively effortful” process to reach their less “natural” conclusion..." 

The U.S. has been awash in the myth of "rugged individualism" since European settlers first arrived, and the expanding "frontier" across the continent. Eastern cultures and even modern west European cultures are much more likely to acknowledge the fact that homo sapiens is a social species. Yes we often compete, but usually as part of a group or team. 

The next question becomes: Who's on our team? This morning I am part of a work team; this evening I will be part of a very different sport team; next weekend I will be part of yet another volunteer/social team. 

West European education systems (especially the Nordic countries, the Netherlands, modern Germany etc.) encourage the concept of social fluidity and tolerance. They encourage generosity towards refugees. Sweden pushes all families to put their toddlers into publicly provided pre-schools that instill Swedish language and values, including tolerance. 

By contrast, conservative American states cut funding for education and stoke fear of "outsiders," pushing an ethos of "self-reliance" including reliance on guns for "self-defense." 

Hoping against hope we can overcome the fear mongering next November.

Rodriguez, 411 U.S. 1 (1973), the "suburbanization" of housing development, "White flight," and the rise of private schools as an alternative to public schools. The only certainty in this matter is that public schools fail or succeed in aiding a rise from the bottom social mobility based on particular local circumstances: how the school taxing district aligns with taxable value of real estate and the political response. My community is fortunate: the school district did not face the rise of separate suburban communities "pulling up the ladders" to keep out lower income residents and leave them with an insufficient tax base. Due to the balkanization of small rural school districts elsewhere in the state, standards are not met. The legislature always says it is doing its best for public schools and higher education, but it has not caught up with the 2008 recession cutbacks. I lived in an impoverished village of several interrelated families in a small democratic nation. It was divided politically between conservatives and liberals.  Both sides contributed leadership and both sides exhibited concern for the well-being of their neighbors.  Dedication to societal and political "values" may seem to be a "soft" factor in group behavior, but it appears to contribute meaning to people's lives.  Why do people search for meaning?  Why is meaning a factor in survival during hard times?  Why does loss of meaning and despair contribute to suicide?  These are questions seldom plumbed by "hard" research.  Nevertheless, this article is informative and helpful.  Yes, education is transformative, but people still cling to the political leaning of their families, even when they become more informed about the views of others and the existence of diversity of views and cultures.  The desire to belong to a group encourages conformity to group values, which enhance acceptance of one by the group.

Empathy is only one human emotion.  There is an ugly side too, anger and hatred, and those are powerful emotions.  Those emotions are in all of us, sometimes we regress into those emotions.  This is why sometimes liberals regress, it's harder for conservatives to evolve, that takes more work.

Anger and hatred is what explains the Trump movement.  It's why when he acts like a bully he becomes more popular not less.  It also explains why the movement is so heavily male.  What we are seeing is a societal regression.  Half of our society has become a circle of middle schoolers cheering on a bully.  It's the making of a lynch mob.  We will pay a price.  Hopefully we snap out of it, but perhaps we wont.

Edsall tries to blame progressives and reactionaries equally for the current climate in America, but that requires ignoring reality. It has been well proven that the more frightened people are, the more  conservative they become.  The fact that people are more liberal when “negative stimuli becoming less prevalent and less deadly,”   and  “when daily threats to life and limb posed by other human beings have diminished” is the basis for understanding how rightwing propaganda machines have  worked throughout history to control minds.  For decades Limbaugh, Fox, Drudge and other Republican propaganda outlets have pushed a lying dystopian narrative that preys on the ignorance, credulity, and fear of the uninformed in order to keep the base frightened and compliant with Republican leadership’s wishes. To argue that progressives should slow or stop any human advancement so as not to upset those frightened, credulous reactionaries is to argue that all human progress has been bad and should therefore cease.  The only real solution to the ignorance, fear and anger of the uninformed and credulous is better education with an emphasis on critical thinking skills and more, not less, pushback against the devious, controlling rightwing propaganda machine.

It is perhaps obvious that when desperate and in fear for their own lives, people might be less generous towards “outsiders” and less tolerant of diversity.
Absent from some of these analyses which tend to focus on psychological issues, is why people are threatened in the first place. 

Why is there job or resource- scarcity? The scarcity produces the “ siege” mentality and intolerance which ( mostly) right-wing politicians and parties create, stoke and exploit.

Mr. Edsall brings up many important ideas explaining Trump persistence. Here is another thought.  There is a craving for masculine energy in the public sphere.  While both masculine and feminine energy are essential for making a working culture, men now are confused about manhood.   There seems to be a cultural message that manhood, by its existence is somehow "bad."  The long held ideal of men as moral humans capable of strength, protection, leadership, clear-eyed reason, moral authority, has been tossed aside and nothing has replaced it.  Add to this that  research indicates that many men are actually friendless, or nearly so.   Enter Rush, Sean, and their ilk.  They don't seem afraid of male energy.   They talk to these fellows (and women too) everyday so they must be their friends, right?  Plus they agree with them on everything!   They are "real guys." They like guns and stuff.

So one explanation of Trump persistence is evidence of a craving for male energy in the public sphere, a huge deficit of real friendships among men, airwaves overtaken by toxic simpletons, and heartbreaking, disturbing and ultimately culture destroying understanding of what is means to "be a man."
If I could ask Trump supporters one question, I think it would be this:  Would you pay the tuition and enroll in Trump University?

These differences in political orientations are the intervening variables. How do the people in each camp come to these views?

1.  Political socialization from childhood on. The tendency is to follow the same general political direction as parents/family, which may be reinforced or change in adulthood due to the socialization pressures of reference groups (education, occupation, friends).

2.  Status Consistency-Inconsistency: 
a. Status Consistent: People who share the demographic characteristics of the dominant group in society (i.e., white, Anglo-Saxon, male, Protestant) are high on ascribed status: they are born with and grow up these traits, & tend to be more conservative & favor the status quo that prefers their traits. Self-protective, they try to keep others down.

b.  Status Inconsistent: People lower on ascribed status but high on achieved (i.e., people of color; women; Jewish, Muslim, atheist; gay; immigrant).  We are more likely to feel we are discriminated against and to identify with others in the same boat & likely to be liberal--open to helping others achieve and succeed--rather than "keeping them in their place."

Note: Avid right-wingers may be high or low income but cling desperately to their high ascribed status of white, Anglo-Saxon, male. 

Trump tapped into: Lower income high ascribed status folks are especially angry, since they see themselves downward mobile because of people higher on achieved status (esp. education) but have lower ascribed status.

The answer is almost ALWAYS the same. They tell me..."Why bother?...nothing in my life will markedly change". Politicians talk and talk and and nothing changes. If anything it gets worse. Karen Stenner decries the “unwillingness of liberals to accept an open debate in which immigration opponents can ‘express their fears and concerns, without being called racists.’” I’m happy to discuss immigration with conservatives or liberals, and I do not take it for granted that those who advocate stricter rules or enforcement are racists. But here’s something that I do want both sides to adopt: the same standards for assessing an argument, involving verifiable and widely accepted data and robust standards for debate. It won’t matter if we put aside tribal epithets but each side subscribes to a different and incompatible set of data and standard of debate. That is where we seem to be, and increasingly so. A case in point: the causes of poverty, as discussed in this essay. Why do conservatives insist that it is irresponsible personal conduct, or unwise use of funds? What data does this depend on? Extrapolation from one or two personal acquaintances? Yesterday’s Rush Limbaugh or Fox and Friends? A cherry-picked data set? We hear a lot about immigrants depressing wages. Would conservatives agree to accept the 2017 National Academies study [https://www.nap.edu/read/23550/chapter/2] that found little effect on overall employment levels of native-born workers, and that overall the inflow of foreign-born workers was a relatively minor factor in the $18 trillion US economy? Will I be called an elitist (the conservative equivalent to ‘racist’) for holding that as valid?

They make alliances and fund politicians who will help them keep it. They use our American mythology of the self-made man and "job creator" to justify the concentration of wealth. So at a time when we desperately need to reduce carbon and methane emissions, the decision-makers and those in control of corporations like Exxon Mobil continue to invest in oil and gas exploration and building new cracking facilities, gas and oil export terminals pipelines, etc. They are confident that they can use conservatism to block efforts to make major changes to the economy.

Dr. Mutz’s observation is worth repeating:

Interestingly enough the graphic provided that indicated conservative, liberal, and moderates viewpoints on reasons for Americans being poor did not include a choice related to equity in educational opportunities, a major omission indeed.

This is a significant factor in one’s ability to overcome “tribalism,” and as such deserves greater attention. The Democratic Party is on the right track in advocating for student loan forgiveness, increasing Pell Grants, and free tuition to 2- and/or 4-year institutions of higher education, and providing additional funding to K-12 school districts whose property taxes based on SES does not provide adequate financing for a quality education.

I would support a politician in Los Angeles, where I live, who had no ideological or political allegiances, who spoke the truth, and tackled difficult issues.

Yet we have an entrenched political establishment who cannot remove "bums/derelicts/homeless/temporarily unsheltered victims/people we must treat with compassion" from the street. We have a policy of soft, then hard, and we fail to do what we should to end this blight.

The solutions: build more housing, free market housing, government housing. Connect taller, denser buildings to a vast public transportation system subsidized by the state and federal government. Fund mental health fully. Insure everyone with medical care.  With a flood of new construction, say 500,000 units, rents will come down as landlords compete for new tenants. 

And if we do all of the above, we will be hit with an onslaught of illegal immigration from Central and South America which will pour in here and move into housing, and take advantage of free medical care and other benefits.  In order to provide decent housing, health care and schools you must limit the amount of people receiving those services.

No wonder we never make any progress in the country.
